Matching Gift Programs

Over the years, the Federation has teamed up with hundreds of organizations to provide matching gift opportunities, empowering both employers and employees with a simple and effective way to give back.

NOTE: The IRS does not consider JFGD to be a religious organization. As a 501(c)(3) corporation, we are required to file a 990 form, and we do so annually. A copy of our 990s can be found here.

Donate Today

  • Double Your Impact

    Most employer programs match contributions dollar for dollar, and some will even double or triple the amount of the gift!

  • Versatility and Flexibility

    Matching gift programs are customizable and can include financial contributions or volunteer hours by employees, retirees, and even employee spouses. Gifts may include monthly payroll deductions as well as annual gifts.

  • Culture of Generosity

    Giving brings people together and cultivates a culture of teamwork and gratitude.

Impact Story

JFGD increases security efforts amid rising antisemitism

By Shana MedelJan 12, 2022

Jewish Federation of Greater Dallas (JFGD) is ramping up security to keep 70,000 community members safe in the Jewish spaces they frequent most.

The efforts come on the back of a 400% spike in antisemitic incidents since Hamas rampaged through Southern Israel, killing more than 1,400 civilians and taking more than 220 hostages. Between Oct. 7-23, there were 312 reported instances of harassment, vandalism, and assault in America, with 190 of them directly linked to the war between Israel and Hamas.

“Jewish communities feel vulnerable,” said Rabbi Mordechai Harris, who serves as chief impact officer of JFGD. “Many organizations in Jewish Dallas want to ensure the safety of their congregants, students, staff, and anyone who could be impacted. We stepped up because we have the expertise.”

For weeks, Dallas police officers have been stationed inside and outside of every Jewish day school, which teaches hundreds of students between the ages of 3 months old to 18 years old. In addition, JFGD has been partnering with local and national intelligence agencies to keep tabs on potential threats and send text updates to staff.

Headline Example

Because of ongoing threats, JFGD has long provided 24/7 security via law enforcement and community partners, said Bill Humphrey, director of community security for JFGD.

He said their success rests on four pillars: establishing and maintaining relationships with law enforcement officials; sending emergency communications to residents; strengthening Jewish spaces to protect them from attacks; and preparing community members to act under threat.

These pillars have informed everyday security efforts, including communication with the Secure Community Network, the official safety and security organization of the North American Jewish community. These efforts also include a series of free trainings, such as “Run-Hide-Fight,” to prepare residents for life-threatening situations.

“Whether you’re going to work, going to school, or going to shul, security has to be at the forefront, the top priority on everybody’s agenda,” Humphrey said.

The surge in antisemitic incidents, of which 296 targeted American synagogues last year alone, have pushed observant communities to grapple with a major security dilemma: How can congregants be alerted of an attack if their phones are powered down and out of reach on Shabbat?

Enter Relay Pro, which creates a screen-free, push-to-talk phone. The Orthodox Union approved use of this handheld device, helping law enforcement notify synagogues of a threat without requiring congregants to actively use technology.

After monthslong training sessions, organized by JFGD, every Orthodox synagogue in the area has implemented Relay Pro. And now, JFGD is rolling out the device for a number of other Jewish institutions, including the Dallas Holocaust and Human Rights Museum.

With frequent visitors, including more than 100,000 people last year, an eye on safety is crucial, said Mike Weaver, director of facilities for the museum.

"Communication is very important in our day-to-day facility security,” Weaver said. “After a lot of research, the Jewish Federation of Greater Dallas has given us the technology to communicate efficiently with the Relay Pro device.”

The security system is also making an impact at Congregation Beth Torah, a Conservative-affiliated synagogue. Katie Babin, who serves as chief administrator, said Relay Pro ensures neighboring Jewish organizations get connected and stay connected — simply and quickly.

Babin said, “This extra layer of security gives us peace of mind, knowing that we’re always a few taps away from help.”

Discover Jewish Dallas

There’s no one-size-fits-all way to be Jewish. And honestly, we love it that way. Discover a joyful, empowering community where the past is remembered, the present is embraced, and the future is hopeful. Welcome home to Jewish Dallas.

Discover Jewish Dallas
Learn More Apply for Funding

Join us to support a strong and vibrant community.

Your contribution sustains vital programs providing assistance to those facing adversity, strengthens Jewish education, fosters cultural enrichment, and cultivates a sense of belonging that transcends generations. With your support, you actively shape the future of our community, ensuring that our values endure and our traditions thrive.

Application Instructions

Save or print a copy of the application and prepare your answers before beginning. Due to software limitations, applications will need to be completed and submitted in one sitting. It is recommended to save a copy of your application for your records.

If you have questions related to the grant application process, we encourage you to email our Israel and Overseas Grant team. If you believe your organization will be unable to meet the requirements to receive grant funding but still wish to apply, please schedule a meeting with Chief Impact Officer Rabbi Mordechai Harris before submitting your grant application(s).

Enriching Jewish life at home and abroad since 1911

Our vision is to cultivate a  dynamic and inclusive community designed to support growth and flourishing at every stage of life. By nurturing Jewish livelihood, health, education, and identity, we seek to enrich lives daily while providing crucial support during times of crisis.

Learn more
Our Mission

To help ensure the continuity of a strong and vibrant Jewish community in Dallas, Israel, and throughout the world.

Uncover your potential

Emerging Leaders represent the future of Jewish Dallas. This select group has the potential to impact our community through philanthropy and volunteerism now and for decades to come. Join a cohort of 30s and 40s with a desire to repair the world, grow into trusted leaders, and serve Jewish organizations across the metroplex.

Jill Anderson
